proposition: The alignment of brain maps is a fascinating aspect of the nervous system.
The alignment of brain maps allows individuals to seamlessly navigate and interact with the world around them.
The alignment of brain maps starts from the day individuals are born.
The brains of individuals begin aligning various maps of their experiences.
One type of map aligned in the brain is motor maps.
Another type of map aligned in the brain is auditory maps.
A third type of map aligned in the brain is visual maps.
The alignment process ensures that the different maps are in perfect register with each other.
The alignment process enables individuals to efficiently respond to stimuli in their environment.
One example of the alignment is demonstrated in how we orient ourselves in response to auditory cues.
We instinctively turn our heads to the right to locate the source of the sound if we hear a sound coming from our right.

The alignment of our visual, auditory, and motor maps ensures that the neurons in our brain responsible for processing sound from the right are coordinated with the neurons that control looking to the right.
The alignment process occurs in a structure known as the superior colliculus.
The superior colliculus contains layers of neurons arranged in a manner analogous to a sandwich.
Neurons that respond to specific directions in auditory space are aligned with neurons that correspond to those same directions in visual space.
This alignment process allows for the integration of sensory information from different modalities.
The integration of sensory information enables us to effectively perceive and respond to our surroundings.
The alignment of brain maps is primarily established during development.
Groundbreaking experiments in the field of neuroplasticity have shown that brain maps are not fixed.
Brain maps can be modified through experience.
Neuroplasticity refers to the brain's ability to reorganize itself in response to new situations or changes in the environment.
Specific experiments were conducted by neuroscientist Eric Knudsen.
Eric Knudsen conducted experiments that demonstrated the malleability of brain maps.
Eric Knudsen's experiments also showed the rules that govern the plasticity of brain maps.
In conclusion, the alignment of brain maps is a fundamental mechanism that underlies our ability to navigate the world and interact with our surroundings.
